title: The secret road: Monte Zoncolan Big Ride
content:
Cyclist
The secret road: Monte Zoncolan Big Ride

Comeglians sits like a button on a Chesterfield sofa, pinned to the valley floor as if tethering the mountains rising biliously at its sides. There are rather a lot of towns like Comeglians in the Carnic Alps, little more than footnotes to the provincial highways yet still somehow containing everything one could need: a restaurant, a supermarket, a post office, a bank, an ironmongers, a hotel.

As we ride I check them off in that order. By the time we pass the fountain – renaissance nymph draining into stone trough – we’ve hit the town limits and we’re on our first climb.

Related Posts

The Mountain of Venice: Italy Big Ride

A new way of seeing: Dolomites Big Ride

Triple Stelvio: Italy and Switzerland Big Ride

This is how Italy’s northern mountains work. As a general rule, trying to build higher up the peaks is like balancing a marble on a seesaw, with the emphasis on the saw, so towns cling to the feet of the jagged limestone cliffs in a way that means most roads out must go up. It’s how Marco has been able to plan a ride that will total just 65km but yet aggregates some 2,800m of ascent.

Even so, he does need a little bit of help to achieve such stats, which is why he has drafted in a notorious friend. The name’s Zoncolan, Monte Zoncolan.

Like father, like son

In his early twenties, Marco looks like he was born on a bike, so too his father. Yet the duo, who run the portentously named Pendenze Periclose cycle tours (translate: ‘dangerous incline’), came to cycling late in their lives, the younger a ‘smoker, drinker, I liked to party’; the older an ‘overweight security guard at the Vatican’.

Emiliano, Marco’s father, made a permanent move here to Arta Terme in northeast Italy, while Marco splits his time between here and his native Rome. Both are excellent adverts for what cycling can do for you, no matter when you take it up. In four years Emiliano has gone from 90kg and 40 cigarettes a day to having made over 100 ascents of the Zoncolan. One hundred. That’s 14 Everests.

In this Emiliano is something of a local legend. The town even threw him a party for his 100th summit, and while Marco’s tally is somewhat less significant, he still knows the climb like the back of a cereal box.

Hence the best word to describe how he talks about the Zoncolan is ‘friend’, a kind of lovable rogue that sits in the Giro d’Italia’s oeuvre like the Angliru does in the Vuelta’s – a savage climb that regularly steals the show.

M

Yet today we won’t be attacking the Zoncolan in the classic style, from Ovaro in the west. Nor shall we do it in ‘reverse’, as the professionals will do on Stage 14 at this year’s Giro, running in from Sutrio to the east.

No, Marco has a third way up his sleeve, and it worries me that it doesn’t appear on any maps. However, for now the Zoncolan is a featureless enemy, too far in the future to see.

We ride through a cobbled tunnel, the sign to our left striking a red line through the word ‘Comeglians’. Just tens of metres later it becomes apparent we’re making our first down-payments on our altitude debt. The vanishing point of the road has moved up in our vision by a few feet and Marco cheerily chimes in with, ‘See, Monte Crostis already.’

Where have you been?

I never cease to be surprised by the climbs in northern Italy. Just when I think I’ve heard of them all, another one sticks its hand up in the crowd and I wonder how on earth I overlooked it until that point. Today that climb is Monte Crostis, 15.5km long and just brushing the underside of 2,000m; average gradient 9%, multiple stretches near 20%.

The initial slopes are steep enough to silence us both and it’s this ceremonial hush that soundtracks the film unspooling in front of me. The road is the kind of grey a wet school jumper goes, with the lack of central markings indicating how narrow it is.

To one side are brilliant green conifers dripping in the morning damp, on the other dozens of stacked logs, bark peeling like chocolate flake from their drying yellow centres. In 2018 the Carnic Alps were ravaged by severe storms, which blew whole mountainsides bald and reduced trees to matchsticks, and nearly two years on loggers are still clearing the fallout.

Two cyclists pass us as we happen upon Tualis, the Crostis’s last meaningful town. They nod with the solemnity of those who know that they’re coming down while you’re going up. Their rushed wind disturbs our quiet air and for a moment a welcome breeze crosses the road. But it is short-lived.

The mid-July temperatures, though far from record-bothering, are enough to bother me, but slowly I can feel the air temperature drop in a way that indicates we are gaining serious height. Still, I can’t see any references in the landscape to our loftier position. Were it not for the road this would be dense forest, and as such trees obscure all but the faintest vertical slithers of view.

Switchbacks start in earnest, the first pairs a quick turn one way followed by a more languid sweep the other, flourishes of a signature written into the pine trees. But like a constrictor they slowly tighten to the kinds of corners that look down upon each other, until finally we emerge into a near-straight that propels us into our first big landscape.

Peaks of purple layer the horizon, while ahead is what looks like sky but what Marco ruefully tells me is mist. It has enveloped the Panoramica delle Vette road that is to be our prize for reaching the Crostis’s top, a gravel pass so named for the sweeping views it offers. Marco says what any cyclist encountering distant mist always says: ‘Don’t worry, it’ll burn off.’ 

Misty eyed

Concerns about visibility disappear more quickly than the land as we enter the last 2km. This was what Marco warned me about, the classic sting in the tale all the best climbs have, as if the road engineers had enough with building and decided they wanted the job finished fast so set about laying the shortest pathway to the top.

Our previous 8-10% intensifies to long stretches of 18%. Like saying a word over and over until it loses meaning, I try to focus so hard on my legs that the burning sensations cease to have any impact. I am entirely unsuccessful.

Marco’s prediction of burning mist is equally off the mark, and instead I can see it descending upon our mountain from all points of the compass. But there is a plan, a stop at the refugio and the assurance of those most hallowed of substances, coffee and cake.

Such thoughts are enough to gee my legs, and though I’ve found the whole experience of the last 20 minutes painful I arrive at the monument that marks the climb’s de facto end pleased, if not precisely happy.

The monument is a strange one in that it appears to celebrate the Giro’s passage along this pass in 2011, but in fact the Giro never ended up coming here. Tragically Belgian rider Wouter Weylandt had a fatal crash on a descent during Stage 3, an incident the Giro’s chief doctor described by saying, ‘I had never seen such a thing before.’ Despite wearing a helmet, the impact was so great forensic investigators believed the rider to have died almost instantly.

This tragedy altered not just the race’s mood but its organisation, with Giro officials scrutinising stage safety all over again. The Crostis is a very narrow road, so much so that race officials initially decreed only motorbikes would be allowed up it, not team cars.

But with the spotlight shone on its technical descent and gravel sections, Crostis was dumped from the race altogether – albeit with the explanation that it was the teams who had objected on the grounds that without team cars they ‘couldn’t fulfil their duties’, hence the Crostis was ejected on ‘sporting’ not ‘safety’ grounds.

Either way, the climb remains unused by Italy’s biggest show on two wheels, which is perhaps why it’s relatively unknown.

Cake and espressos are forthcoming, as is my jacket from my jersey pocket. More mist encroaches and our perch on the terrace of Refugio Chiandinas becomes a frigid affair. We mull over how long we should wait – will the mist lift or will it worsen, and how long before our freezing limbs organise a mutiny? We reach total whiteout. We wait. I sit on my hands having ascertained there is no hot water in the toilet taps.

To a degree our stubbornness pays off. The white turns wispy grey, and if not the sprawling views promised then at least I can now see 10 metres up the road, most useful given that the next few kilometres are gravel with a precipitous unguarded drop to our right.

Eventually we get low enough to evade the mist and a boldly lush valley reaches out before us. Crostis peaked then plateaued at 1,982m, so it’s no surprise and tremendous fun that the next 20km are all downhill, with barely a pedal stroke spent to power us to Sutrio.

Ignore them

The descent has been rejuvenating, our bodies warmed by the breaking sun on the way down. We pass into the town limits of Sutrio and I see several signs pointing towards the Zoncolan. We pass each one with a wag of Marco’s finger. We then leave Sutrio altogether and I’m left scratching my head as to how we’re gong to arrive at a climb we’re basically now cycling away from.

Marco hollers and brakes suddenly. We’ve overshot the turn, and when we retrace our steps I can see why. Like Comeglians this morning, the village that marks our turning is a blink-and-you’ll-miss-it clutch of buildings with one road in and one road out.

We take the road in, just after a sign stating ‘Priola’; weave through a few streets barely wide enough for a horse, and then suddenly what feels like someone’s driveway disappears off and up into thick forest. This is the old road up the Zoncolan I was promised. And what a horrendous promise it is.

Had we made our start in Sutrio as the pros will come May, the first few kilometres’ gradient would roll along in single digits, and even when the road crossed to 10% at least there it would stay until the last brutal 3km. And even then the road is at least newish and well surfaced.

Our road, however, can probably recall Luigi Ganna winning in 1909 and is more trodden in by hooves than tarmacked for vehicles. Here we’re straight in at 11%, the road spiking like an arrhythmic heart to the high teens. My rear wheel slips when I stand yet my front grows unnervingly light when I sit. It’s like riding up an abandoned multi-storey car park.

However, while Monte Crostis presented a significant challenge, this is so ridiculous in its gradient and road condition that it takes every bit of grit and focus I can muster not to get off and walk.

Somehow Marco manages some chatter, to which I would tell him not to bother if I could manage any words of my own. As it is I’m content to let him drift into the pines while I try to look through my fogged lenses to avoid fallen branches and pick the least rutted lines. I should have removed my glasses at the bottom, but my hands now have permanent contracts working at my handlebars.

As they say, suffering produces perseverance; perseverance builds character, and character hope – and it’s true. The more storeys of this car park I tick off, the more I hope it will end.

Instead the road becomes more like a footpath, with tree branches and bushes clawing at my sides like sinister fans on a col (I later look on Google Maps and officially the road just dead-ends). And then, as if by magic, the sun grows bright and I emerge onto a smoothly tarmacked road to see neat fields, a picturesque chalet and a smiling Marco. ‘Now the climb is hard,’ he says.

I would say keep an eye out on Giro TV coverage for where our old road joins up with the new road, but I doubt you’ll see it. It’s just that hard to spot.

View from the top

Strange to say, but although the climb is steeper still – steady early teens shooting up in patches to near 20% – I find the last third quite palatable. Perhaps my legs have adjusted, but moreover I can now glimpse that cycling panacea: the summit. I can see the silhouetted tops of trees indicating no further height can be gained, and those trees are actually getting closer.

The climb is also getting progressively easier in the sense that I have sweated out a day’s ration of water and now emptied my water bottles. I wonder when someone will invent a Garmin add-on to measure bodyweight during a ride.

Marco is now climbing like a salsa dancer on a winch, all hips and glide, and by the time I reach the top he has his phone out, snapping pictures of the Zoncolan signage to send to his dad. I collapse onto my handlebars, chest heavy, limbs floating somewhere overhead, at last safe in the knowledge the only way is down.

How steep thee are

Three ways to the top. And a curveball

There are three ways up Monte Zoncolan. The ‘classic’ ascent averages 11.5% over 10.5km from Ovaro to the west, and is usually how the climb appears in the Giro d’Italia. However this year’s peloton will approach from Sutrio to the east, a longer 13.5km climb but less steep at 8.9%. Both still feature lengthy stretches in the high teens though.

Our Big Ride ascent is the shortest of all – 8.9km from Priola – but it averages 12.8% with multiple spikes up to 22% from the off (the other two routes steepen as they go). But whichever way you approach the Zoncolan, know that it is tough with a capital T. And yet there is an even tougher climb just down the road.

A few clicks west of Ovaro lies the Passo della Forcella, a 9.2km long climb with a 14.4% average, a kilometre at 20.9% and another 2km at 17.7%. Worse still it’s often strewn with leaves and much of the surface is slab concrete. Why not give it a go?

The rider’s ride

FiftyOne Disc, £12,000 (£6,000 frameset), fiftyonebikes.com

There’s something about a FiftyOne that always makes me think that, for the right customer, it will prove a brilliant investment. First, because it is fully bespoke it fits like the proverbial glove, but second, because it is round-tubed it won’t date, yet custom paint means it will be forever unique. It looks classily current now; it will look the same in 10 years’ time (and if you spread the cost over 10 years it will only set you back £3.29 a day). And then there’s the ride.

I’ve ridden both rim and disc brake FiftyOnes, and both hit that precise sweet-spot of focussed handling paired with exceptional balance, specifically in terms of stiffness, where the frame reacts and flexes as it negotiates turns yet smashes powerfully out of corners, into sprints and up climbs.

Round tubes are just very good at promoting this sort of ride feel, but it also helps if you source the best round tubes from Enve and Deda and put them together in a meticulous fashion. I’ve been to see this Dublin builder’s work in progress and the craftsmanship is as good as it gets. It almost seems a shame to paint a FiftyOne. But then you do, and it looks like this.

How we did it

Travel

Venice Marco Polo is the best airport for flying cheaply. From there it’s a two-hour drive to Arta Terme via the faster toll roads – expect to pay around €15 each way – but we’d recommend going cross-country for a more scenic passage. 

Accommodation

The Grand Hotel Gortani is a classically Italian hotel in Arta Terme, with spacious rooms, spa, swimming pool and well-kept gardens. Double rooms start at around £70pn in June. See gortani.it for more details. 

Thanks

Big thanks to Marco Cantagallo, who planned our route and guided us enthusiastically, his father Emiliano for lending us Marco (he is usually a bike guide) and Mauricio, who drove our photographer and dished up an impromptu picnic. Emiliano and Marco run Pendenze Periclose bike tours (pendenzepericolose.it). Thanks also to the Grand Hotel Gortani’s manager, Chiara, for being so accommodating of bicycles and early breakfasts.
